trans-unit.source: Indicates the type of input that the grammar, defined by the <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument"></xref>, will match.
The input mode for an <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument> is determined by its <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument.Mode%2A> property.
The default input mode is Voice, which indicates that the grammar defined by the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument> will match speech input.
The Dtmf mode indicates that a grammar will match Dual-Tone Multi-Frequency (DTMF) tones instead of speech.
There are 16 DTMF tones, 12 of which are commonly found on most telephones.

When you create a <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.Grammar> object from an <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument>, the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.Grammar> object will match the type of input specified by the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument.Mode%2A> property, which gets an instance of SrgsGrammarMode.
The <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument"></xref> object will match DTMF tones similar to those found on a telephone, instead of speech.
The <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument"></xref> object will match speech input.
